III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12505
Section (2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
Description (b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying with
the terms of the contract required by R 400.12510, continues to
reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and is managing
expenditures.
Violation Potential Rule or Statue Violation.
Type
Allegation Youth A disclosed that she does not feel safe in the home due to
young men are allowed to enter the premises freely.
Investigation Complainant/Complaint document
On 10/7/2022 I reviewed the complaint and attempted contact with
the complainant.
The complaint indicated Youth A stated she does not feel safe
because young men are allowed to enter the premises and roam
freely. Additionally, that the young men hang around outside the
facility, and proposition the youths to get into their vehicles as the
youths leave or are outside the facility. The complaint did not
indicate how Youth A knew this or when it had occurred.
DHHS Worker XX
On 10/7/2022 I spoke with the Department of Health and Human
Services (DHHS) Worker XX by telephone. DHHS Worker XX is
not an assigned worker on this complaint. DHHS Worker XX
contacted me related to the complaint in an attempt to obtain
information related to the extent of the complaint. She shared
3

information about her connection to the agency. She reported that
she/her county received an email from another county office
advising her/them that county had completed an emergency
replacement of a youth they had placed at this Independent Living
(IL) facility; and advising DHHS Worker XX’s county’s office their
youth may have safety issues at the facility.
DHHS Worker XX reported she completed an unannounced onsite
to the facility related to Youth B. DHHS Worker XX reported she
observed the independent living (IL) house to be “okay, no clutter,
no dishes in the sink; no men hanging around outside”. She
reported the agency indicated they installed cameras and other
windows because Youth B snuck someone into the home. She
reported speaking with Youth B and Youth B reported she feels
safe in this placement. DHHS Worker XX provided me a copy of
four photos (kitchen, living room, another outer area and Youth
B’s bed room) she took of the IL house, which showed no areas of
concern.
Service Worker X
On 10/10/2022 I interviewed Youth A’s DHHS worker, Service
Worker X by telephone. Service Worker X reported information in
this complaint came out during a court hearing attended by the
agency and Youth A on 9/28/2022. Service Worker X reported an
emergency hearing was held on Friday (9/30/2022) at which time
the court ordered Youth A’s replacement that occurred that day.
Service Worker X denied Youth A having special needs of a
cognitive nature.
Service Worker X said she received a call from the attorney
general (AG) on 10/6/2022 with instructions to explore the matter.
Service Worker X reported the court was upset after Youth A
reported she was being bullied at school, was not in therapy and
that reportedly the agency had done nothing about it. Additionally,
that Youth A reported that men were hanging around outside the
home when Youth A and other youths left for school, and the men
were propositioning them. Furthermore, that despite the youth
telling the agency about the latter issue, the agency had done
nothing about the issue. Another issue was that there are mice in
the home.
Service Worker X reported a meeting occurred with the agency on
10/6/2022. The agency denied men hanging around the IL home.
The agency indicated that men in cars have driven by the house;
and some may have blown their horn after seeing a youth outside,
but no men were propositioning the youths. Service Worker X
4

was not sure what the agency were doing or had done related to
the issue of mice being seen in the home.
Youth A
I made several attempts to contact Youth A about these
allegations without success.
Onsite Agency Visit and Interviews
On 10/14/2022 I interviewed Youth C, Case Manager 3,
Independent Living (IL) Site Worker 4 and IL Site worker 5 onsite
related to the allegations of mice, and of men hanging round the
home creating safety issues.
During this onsite visit, I also attempted to interview Youth B; and I
completed a tour of the facility.
Youth B
Youth B refused to talk with me. Nor would Youth B report
whether she did or did not feel safe at the facility.
Youth C:
Youth C reported being in placement at the agency for
approximately five months. She reported she had denied the Orkin
people access to her room, because they come at 9:00am or
10:00am and she is sleeping. She reported to have caught mice
on a sticky track that was in her room. Youth C did not know how
long ago that was. She has not seen any mice in her room or
other parts of the home since that time. Youth C added that she
does not leave her room much.
Youth C reported there had been two or three men hanging
around outside. Youth C said that was about one month ago and
it had been one male person at a time, at different times, not
multiple males together. She reported the male persons had been
there for Youth B, and all had occurred before the agency installed
the camera’s outside in September 2022. Youth C reported no
men/males have been around since that time. She reported
knowing the male persons were there for Youth B, because Youth
B talked about it, and when Youth B would go outside the male
person would be there. Youth C said she also knew the male
person was there for Youth B because Youth B had snuck a boy,
“not a man” in the house more than once. Youth C reported it was
not that hard to sneak a person inside without staff’s knowledge,
because of where the stairs leading upstairs are located with
respect to the front door; as well as, where a downstairs bedroom
is located. Youth C reported seeing more than one boy in the
5

home that Youth B had snuck into Youth B’s room. Youth C
reported not telling staff about this at first, but eventually doing so
because she realized it could be unsafe for males to be in the
home. Youth C denied any males that Youth B had snuck into the
home ever talking with her or coming to her room. Youth C
reported other than the staff talking with Youth B, nothing else
occurred, that she was aware of. Youth C was not aware of
whether staff had ever caught a male person in the house.
Agency Staff
All the staff interviewed admitted there had been an issue with
mice in the past and that the agency was or had addressed it. All
these staff reported Orkin visited the home regularly; and that any
infestations that had occurred was due to a lack of cleanliness by
the youths, despite the youths being encouraged to clean up after
themselves.
Case Manager 3:
Case Manager 3 reported there are currently only two youths in
the program. Youth A had been the third youth, and Youth A was
ordered replaced from the IL home on 9/30/2022 based
apparently on inaccurate information reported by Youth A to the
court on 9/28/2022. Case Manager 3 reported being in
attendance at that court hearing, but not being able to address the
court to explain the issues Youth A reported. Each time she tried
she said she was cut off. She reported the agency was not aware
there would be an emergency replacement until 9/30/2022. Case
Manager 3 reported at the next hearing on 10/13/2022, she was
able to give feedback and explain.
Case Manager 3 reported Orkin was at the home most recently on
10/7/2022 around 2:00pm and Youth C refused to allow Orkin into
her room. She reported the pest issue had already been
addressed prior to this complaint issue.
Case Manager 3 denied ever witnessing men anywhere outside
around the house. She reported asking her staff about this issue
and the staff had not seen any men as well. If there were men
hanging around, she said she and the staff would call the police.
She reported that on 9/22/2022, she met with the youths one-to-
one; after Youth C reported to a staff that there had been a man in
the house. Case Manager 3 said each youth knows it is against
the rules to have men/people in the house; and her meeting with
them was to again advise them of the rule, and possible safety
issues, and consequences attached to that. Case Manager 3
reported Youth A had also reported a youth had snuck a male into
6

the home. Case Manager 3 said Youth A reported that she told
the youth (name not reported) it was not cool to have men in the
home. Youth A would not report how the person got into the home
or whether she had assistance in any way; only that the person
left while the staff (name was not disclosed) was in the bathroom.
Case Manager 3 reported that it had it only been the one incident
she was aware of, but Youth C said this type of thing happened
twice. Case Manager 3 reported not knowing if that information by
Youth C was accurate, because Youth C was upset with Youth B
at the time Youth C reported it. Case Manager 3 reported the
alleged incident had taken place on the third shift. Reportedly, the
boy Youth B had at the house left, and a second person, (who
was the ride to the boy who had come to the home) had come to
the home separately. Reportedly, the latter boy had come to pick
up the other boy, not knowing the boy had left the home. A safety
plan was done after that incident related to the one-to-one
meeting with the youths, continued room checks by staff, and the
cameras installed outside.
Site Worker 4 and Site Worker 5
Site Worker 4 reported working primarily first shift (7:00am-
3:00pm) and Site Worker 5 works second shift 3:00pm-11:00pm.
Both site workers reported information about the pest issue as
indicated earlier in this section.
Site Worker 4 reported Youth A never mentioned anything to her
about men hanging around outside the house or being allowed
inside the house. Site Worker 4 said men are not allowed in the
home. She reported that some time in July 2022 Youth B alleged
that Youth A had allowed a male into the home, but Site Worker 4
denied ever seeing a male in the home. Nor of any other youth
reporting such an incident to her. Site Worker 4 reported that prior
to this complaint the agency used to have outside cameras to
survey the area, but the cameras died, and Program Director 2
never replaced the cameras until about two weeks ago.
Site Worker 5 reported she learned about an incident of Youth B
sneaking a male into the home about three weeks ago. She said
the incident occurred on a Tuesday around 8:00pm during a
second shift that she did not work. Site Worker 5 was not sure
whether the male person was caught by staff or if staff learned
about the matter after the fact. Site Worker 5 was not aware of
another incident of a male person being in the home. She reported
what Case Manager 3 had about a second male coming to the
house on the day of the first incident. This second male person
had come onto the porch and pulled on the door knob and left.
7

Program Director 2
On 10/17/2022 I spoke with Program Director (PD) 2 by telephone
and had email correspondences with him on 10/7/2022 and
10/14/2022 about the allegations. PD 2 reported Samaritas along
with Orkin has placed extra traps down related to the mice issue.
He reported the agency has a plan in place whereby Orkin visits
the home monthly to address any pest issues. This system has
been in place for quite some time. He reported recent service
dates of 7/1/2022, 7/7/2022, 8/1/2022, 9/9/2022 and 10/7/2022.
There was also past documentation showing services in April,
May and June 2022.
PD 2 reported that since the agency’s last investigation they have
placed cameras outside the home to survey the area and help
with safety monitoring. Additionally, they continue to talk with the
youths about inviting males over, because such visits are against
the IL home’s rules. The staff are encouraged to provided greater
checks of/about the home.
Reviewed:
Documentation showing the home was sprayed/inspected for
pest on:
• 4/1/2022, 4/5/2022, 6/5/2022, 6/8/2022, 7/1/2022, 7/7/2022;
8/1/2022; 9/9/2022 and 10/7/2022 as indicated by PD 2.
Toured the IL home on 10/14/2022.
No rodents/pest were observed in the home at that time. Aside
from the bathrooms and one of the youths’ bedrooms needing
cleaning, no major concerns were observed. The outside cameras
that staff reported had been installed were seen.
Analysis The agency was addressing and continues to address issues
related to pests in the home, which was due partly to youths
leaving food in their rooms/about the home, and not cleaning up
behind themselves. At the time of the tour there was no evidence
of rodents or pests, and the facility was basically clean.
Additionally, the matter of men hanging around the home relates
to at least one youth sneaking a boy into the home; a matter that
was addressed with that youth and other youths in the home.
There is insufficient evidence to support the allegations or the
home/environment being unsafe.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
8

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statue Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency has not offered supportive services to the youth. The
youth has been at the facility for 6 months and has not had any
therapy. The agency is not looking into relatives as placements.
Investigation On 10/7/2022 I reviewed the complaint and attempted contact with
the complainant.
Service Worker X
On 10/10/2022 I spoke with Youth A’s DHHS worker, Service
Worker X by telephone. Service Worker X reported information in
this complaint came out during a court hearing attended by the
agency and Youth A on 9/28/2022. Service Worker X said she
received a call from the attorney general (AG) on 10/6/2022 with
instructions to explore the matter. Service Worker X reported the
court was upset after Youth A reported she was being bullied at
school, was not in therapy and that reportedly the agency had
done nothing about it.
Service Worker X reported Youth A was supposed to be in
therapy but was not. Service Worker X reported the agency
indicated they tried to provide Youth A with services, but Youth A
was resistant. The agency reported they tried to put Youth A in
therapy, but Youth A kept refusing to attend and the agency gave
no other particulars related the therapy matter.
Service Worker X reported the agency was also supposed to be
assisting with sibling visits or providing bus tickets but did not
appear to be doing so. For transportation, the agency reported
providing bus tickets. Service Worker X reported that Youth A
wanted a direct drive provided by agency staff.
Youth A
I made several attempts to contact Youth A about these
allegations without success.
9

Onsite Agency Visit and Interviews
On 10/14/2022 I interviewed Youth C, Case Manager 3 (who I
also had email correspondence with on 10/12/2022), Independent
Living (IL) Site Worker 4 and IL Site worker 5, onsite related to the
allegations. I also attempted to interview Youth B. On 10/17/2022,
I spoke with Program Director (PD) 2 by telephone and had email
correspondences with him on 10/7/2022 and 10/14/2022 about the
allegations.
Youth B
Youth B refused to talk with me about the allegations.
RE: School bulling:
Youth C
Youth C reported she attends school online. She reported
knowing at some point that Youth A attended school in the
community, but Youth C was not aware of Youth A being bullied at
school. Youth A never mentioned being bullied. Youth C said,
Youth A told her boys at school were trying to talk with her, and
Youth A reported not wanting to be bothered with the boys.
Youth C said Youth A had mentioned the latter to a staff person,
but Youth C did not know what staff person Youth A had
mentioned that to; nor when, or what, if any suggestions were
advised by the staff person.
Case Manager 3
Case Manager 3 denied Youth A ever speaking with her about
being bullied at school. Case Manager 3 said Youth A did not
want to go to school; and staff would report Youth A would not get
up for school. Case Manager 3 said Youth A gave numerous
reasons for not getting up and going to school. Case Manager 3
reported Youth A’s first day of school was on 9/14/2022. She
reported in the two-week period between 9/14/2022 and
9/30/2022 (when Youth A left the IL home), Youth A only went to
school four days. Case Manager 3 reported trying to talk with
Youth A about school, and what if anything was going on. She
said, Youth A’s comments about the school were that it was
“ghetto,” she did not like the school, it was chaotic, and the
teachers did not have control of the classrooms. Case Manager 3
reported at some unspecified time, Youth A reported a boy was
bothering or touching her on her first day of school. Youth A would
not provide details as to what that meant; and Youth A had not
reported that on her first day of school. Case Manager 3 said
Youth A’s comments came out a little bit at a time over the two-
week period. Case Manager 3 said Youth A would not answer the
10

explorative questions she asked and would walk away. Case
Manager 3 advised that Youth A also had a computer, and even if
she was not physically going to class, Youth A could go online and
do schoolwork, but Youth A did not. The school reported Youth A
was not completing work online as required.
Case Manager 3 reported trying to make contact with the school
about Youth A’s hours, whether she was being bullied and how
Youth A was doing. On 9/30/2022, she connected with the school
principal. The principal reported at no time had Youth A reported
being bullied or that anything had happened at school. The
principal reported running a tight ship; no students are allowed to
roam about. That outside of one incident of fighting and one
student being caught vaping (not Youth A), there have been no
noted school issues.
Site Worker 4 and Site Worker 5
Site Worker 4 reported not knowing of a time Youth A was being
bullied at school. She said Youth A was only in school about 10
days during the school year, prior to Youth A leaving the program.
Site Worker 4 said she took Youth A for five of those days and
Youth A was absent the rest of the days. She said Youth A
refused to take the bus or walk home, and Site Worker 4 would
also pick Youth A up from school. Site Worker 4 said Youth A
never reported being bullied or any school concerns.
Site Worker 5 reported Youth A would periodically talk with her
about school. Youth A told her she did not like school and that
people at the school were bothering her, but Youth A gave no
details. Youth A talked about being anxious about things in
general and being sexually active. Site Worker 5 reported
speaking with Case Manager 3 about what Youth A reported three
or four times after the youths’ group sessions. Case Manager 3
responded that “we will try to look into that”. Site Worker 5
reported Case Manager 3 spoke with Youth A and all the youths
after group. Site Worker 5 was not sure what came about those
talks with Youth A.
Program Director 2
Program Director 2 indicated the current case manager, Case
Manager 3 has worked extensively with the school, but Youth A
and another youth in the home has refused to even go to school.
He did not report an awareness that Youth A was being bullied at
school or had reported such.
RE: Therapy:
11

Youth C
Youth C was not aware of whether Youth A was receiving or not
receiving therapy.
Case Manager 3
Case Manager 3 reported Youth A was not in therapy when Case
Manager 3 officially took over case manager in August 2022.
Case Manager 3 reported there was a transfer meeting between
she and Case Manager 6 where it was reported that Case
Manager 6 attempted to get Youth A into therapy, but Youth A
cancelled the intake appointment. Case Manager 3 denied Youth
A reporting anxieties but admitted a staff (that person was not
named) told her Youth A reported having anxieties. On
9/28/2022, Case Manager 3 said she contacted Genesee Health
Center and made an appointment for 9/30/2022. On 9/30/2022,
she advised Youth A that she would be transporting Youth A to
the appointment. Youth A refused to go to the appointment and
told Case Manager 3 she did not care what Case Manager 3 did;
she was not going. Case Manager 3 cancelled the 9/30/2022
appointment and rescheduled it for 10/3/2022. Case Manager 3
reported this was all done before they knew Youth A was leaving
the program. She reported after Youth A’s emergency
replacement, she completed a JAC (Juvenile Assessment Center)
referral to assist with therapy in the new placement.
Site Worker 4 and Site worker 5
Site Worker 4 did not know if Youth A was or was not in therapy.
Site Worker 5 reported that Youth A had reported being open to
therapy, but Youth A’s actions did not show that. Site Worker 5
reported that when Case Manager 6 tried to set up therapy for
Youth A, Youth A would say I don’t feel like it. Site Worker 5
reported knowing this because it was reported to her. She said in
August 2022 Case Manager 6 tried to get services set up via
Genesee Health System, but they were not taking referrals at that
time. Site Worker 5 reporting knowing the latter, because she is
the one who called the community health care agency to get an
intake appointment. She spoke with Case Manager 6 after the
call and Case Manager 6 advised they would have to find
something else. Site Worker 5 was not aware of what happened
after that, or what Case Manager 3 followed up on.
Program Director 2
PD 2 reported hearing from Case Manager 6 of Youth A being
resistant to attending therapy, and not being willing to complete an
intake. He indicated case service referrals for Hope Network and
12

Genesee Health System were completed by Case Manager 6 in
September 2022 and documented in MISACWIS. He provided a
copy of the 10/4/2022 referral to the JAC by Case Manager 3.
RE: Transportation/Relative placement:
Youth C
Youth C reported knowing Youth A had asked about
transportation (she did not say how she knew that) to go see
Youth A’s sister; but Youth C did not know whether the agency
had provided that transportation. Youth C affirmed that the
agency provides bus tickets.
Case Manager 3
Case Manager 3 reported all youths that wish to go visit a family
member must first provide a name, phone number and address of
the person(s) they wish to see. She reported that Samaritas
encourages family contact and visitation; but they must first look at
the youth’s safety related to anyone the youth seeks to visit.
She reported it was not until August 2022, while on a camping trip
and again in September 2022 during a Life Skills Meeting that
Youth A asked to get a weekend pass to visit someone down in
the Detroit area. Youth A refused to provide the name of the
person in Detroit. When Case Manager 3 pressed the matter with
Youth A, Youth A still would not name the person she wanted to
visit but reported the person would not speak to Case Manager 3
because “they hated Samaritas”. She told Youth A bus passes
could be provided and that Case Manager 3 would also help with
transportation. Youth A still did not provide an address until later in
September when Youth A gave her sister’s name and information
and said she wanted to live with that sister.
Site Worker 4 and Site worker 5
Both of these workers reported they were not aware of Youth A
ever requesting transportation to visit a relative or anyone.
Site Worker 4 reported Youth A having siblings, but she did recall
Youth A visiting them and Site Worker 4 did not know why that
was.
Site Worker 5 reported Youth A going on two to four overnight
visits during Youth A’s placement. Someone would pick up and
drop Youth A off. Site Worker 5 was not sure who those visits
were with as visits are approved by the IL case manager or
director.
13

Youth A
I made several attempts to contact Youth A via her sister, about
these allegations without success.
Program Director 2
PD 2 reported whenever the agency gets placement of a youth
from another region, they do not have a problem helping with
youth/relative visitation. They always provide a way for transport
of a youth if the youth cannot find a way or if the relative cannot
pick up the youth. He reported the agency also teaches youths
how to get around on the bus. PD 2 was not certain whether the
latter had occurred with Youth A but surmised it likely had not. Nor
that Youth A would know how to catch the bus from Flint to Detroit
where her sister resides. He reported therefore, the agency would
have had to coordinated that with Youth A and her sister. He
reported the agency would have looked at purchasing a bus ticket
for her. He reported when Youth A first came into placement
Youth A reported she did not get along with her relatives. Youth A
did not want or request relative visitation until the last couple of
weeks in September 2022. He said Youth A had not engaged in
the IL program because Youth A did not want to be there.
PD 2 reported the agency would only explore a relative placement
when a youth was ready to transition to a relative placement,
which had not been the situation prior to the emergency
placement removal. He said the agency never got that far with
visitation for Youth A or with a relative placement. He said DHHS
wanted Youth A in IL placement and another Samaritas IL was to
pick up Youth A’s case. He reported not being sure why the
court/DHHS did the emergency placement removal, noting that
the court placed Youth A with her sister without a full assessment.
Samaritas followed up and completed that assessment.
Reviewed
Youth A’s MISACWIS case which showed:
• She is a temporary court ward. She was placed in this
agency’s IL home on 6/16/2022 until 9/30/2022, with her
official discharge listed in MISACWIS as 10/4/2022.
• Agency court report from Samaritas dated 8/5/2022
completed by Case Manager 6 for Youth A that indicated:
➢ “A relative search was conducted by the previous
placement prior to the move but no fit and willing
relatives were located”. That it is in the youth’s best
interest to remain in her current placement as
adoption is no longer an appropriate permanency
plan.
14

➢ Youth A verbalized she would like therapy services
when she first came into the independent living
plus- ILP program but Youth A has since decided
she does not need therapy. Youth would not make
the initial intake call with the worker because she
did not want to participate in therapy services.
• Updated service plan 4/18/2022-7/16/2022 completed by
Agency Z, the youth’s prior placement agency, that
indicated:
➢ Samaritas and Youth A would contact community
mental health to begin therapy.
• A MISACWIS service provider need/referral for Hope
Network for 9/20/2022 through 10/14/2022; Genesee
County Community Health for 9/20/2022 and Assured
